title: reference request - Dislocations and Random Matrix Theory
body: Does anyone have a good reference book that works as a good starting point for an analyst to learn about the connection between Random Matrix Theory and Dislocations ? Thank you for your help. By dislocations , I mean those that are present in materials as defects in their crystalline structure. More specifically, dislocations that form grain boundaries. A more precise question would be, is there literature outlining the way to describe dislocation distributions via random matrix theory? reference-request pr.probability ap.analysis-of-pdes calculus-of-variations textbook-recommendation Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jul 26, 2020 at 11:02 asked Jul 25, 2020 at 14:37 spaceman 605 3 3 silver badges 15 15 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 4 $\begingroup$ What type of "dislocations" are you interested in? Vortices in superdconductors (as in arxiv.org/abs/1603.06287 )? Singularities of complex wave fields (as in core.ac.uk/download/pdf/30807.pdf ). You really want to be more specific for a helpful answer. $\endgroup$ Carlo Beenakker –  Carlo Beenakker 2020-07-25 16:11:53 +00:00 Commented Jul 25, 2020 at 16:11 $\begingroup$ Hi @CarloBeenakker, thank you for that remark. Yes, that makes sense. By dislocations, I mean those that form grain boundaries in materials. $\endgroup$ spaceman –  spaceman 2020-07-26 10:59:06 +00:00 Commented Jul 26, 2020 at 10:59 $\begingroup$ thank you for the clarification; I am not aware of any application of that type; typical applications to RMT involve some sort of repulsion between the defects, which are then modeled by eigenvalue repulsion; I don't think that grain boundaries "repel" in any obvious way, because they are frozen and lack dynamics; perhaps you can inform us where the idea comes from, that RMT might be applicable to grain boundaries? $\endgroup$ Carlo Beenakker –  Carlo Beenakker 2020-07-26 11:40:18 +00:00 Commented Jul 26, 2020 at 11:40 $\begingroup$ Not sure if RMT is applicable, but here's a work related spectral graph theory to grain boundary modeling: Johnson, Oliver K., Jarrod M. Lund, and Tyler R. Critchfield. "Spectral graph theory for characterization and homogenization of grain boundary networks." Acta Materialia 146 (2018): 42-54. $\endgroup$ Piyush Grover –  Piyush Grover 2020-07-26 20:25:00 +00:00 Commented Jul 26, 2020 at 20:25 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
